name: Siege of Manchester — Civil War Plan (1642)
description: Plan of the Siege of Manchester, September 1642. Lord Strange's Royalist forces besieged the Parliamentarian town. Defenders built barricades, chains across streets, and earthwork defences. Siege plans were commonly drawn in the Civil War.
notes:
RESEARCH TARGET: HIGH PRIORITY — siege plans almost certainly survive.

September 1642: Lord Strange (Earl of Derby) attacks Manchester with Royalist forces.
Manchester defended by Parliamentarians under Colonel John Rosworm (German military engineer).
Defenders built:
- Earth ramparts and ditches around the town
- Chains across streets
- Barricades at key entry points
- Defensive positions at the bridges

Manchester successfully held — one of the first Parliamentarian victories.
Rosworm later complained he was never properly paid.

Where to find siege plans:
- British Library: King's Topographical Collection (K.Top) — Civil War maps
- The National Archives (TNA): State Papers, Civil War period
- Chetham's Library — holds Civil War era material for Manchester
- 'Atlas of the English Civil War' by P.R. Newman (1985)
- 'The Great Civil War in Lancashire' by Ernest Broxap (1910)
- John Rylands Library — Mainwaring and other Civil War collections
- Bodleian Library — Civil War maps collection
- Thomason Tracts (BL) — contemporary pamphlets often included plans

Rosworm's own description of the defences may survive.
Compare with the c.1650 plan (source 25) — drawn only 8 years after the siege.
The 1650 plan's 'Acres Field' (key item E) may have been used as a defensive position.

Also search for:
